title: Basic Etiquette

metadata.author: Nina Evason
metadata.note: All research and editorial content is developed and curated by Mosaica.

description: Basic etiquette in Malaysia is strongly influenced by respect for elders, religious values, and social harmony.

guidelines.text: Give or receive anything with two hands. If something must be passed with one hand, use the right hand, as the left hand is traditionally reserved for cleansing.
It is considered disrespectful to smoke around elderly individuals.
Avoid touching or passing objects over the top of someone’s head, as the head is considered sacred by some Malaysians.
Pointing, especially with the right hand, is viewed as poor manners. Use the right thumb with fingers folded instead.
Do not walk over someone’s crossed legs or cross your own legs in front of elders.
When walking past an elder, it is respectful to bow or bend slightly so that your head is lowered.
Some Malaysians do not consume alcohol due to Islamic, Hindu, or Buddhist beliefs, and this should be respected.
Smoking cigarettes around Malays may be considered impolite, as many abstain for religious reasons.
Malaysians generally have a relaxed attitude toward time, although punctuality may vary across ethnic groups and between urban and rural areas.
